conclusion: The problem involves analyzing the \( U-I \) characteristics of a silicon photovoltaic cell and a resistor to find the internal resistance of the photovoltaic cell.

premise: The graph shows two lines: line \( a \) representing the \( U-I \) characteristic of the silicon photovoltaic cell and line \( b \) representing the \( U-I \) characteristic of the resistor.
conclusion: Line \( a \) and line \( b \) intersect at a point where the current is \( 0.2 \, 	ext{A} \) and the voltage is \( 2.5 \, 	ext{V} \).

premise: The graph shows the open-circuit voltage of the silicon photovoltaic cell as \( 3.6 \, 	ext{V} \).
conclusion: The open-circuit voltage \( E \) of the silicon photovoltaic cell is \( 3.6 \, 	ext{V} \).

premise: The internal resistance \( r \) of the silicon photovoltaic cell can be calculated using the formula \( r =  rac{E - U}{I} \), where \( E \) is the open-circuit voltage, \( U \) is the voltage across the cell at the intersection point, and \( I \) is the current.
conclusion: The internal resistance \( r \) of the silicon photovoltaic cell is \(  rac{3.6 \, 	ext{V} - 2.5 \, 	ext{V}}{0.2 \, 	ext{A}} = 5.5 \, \Omega \).
